Guidance: If the patient has a cardiac condition such as acute myocardial infarction, ensure to include Aspirin in the prescription for its antiplatelet effects unless contraindicated.
When making changes to medication dosage or frequency, document the reasons for modification to ensure clarity and continuity of care.

Trigger Condition: Diagnosis of Intra-parenchymal Hemorrhage.
Recommended Action: Focus on optimizing pain management tailored to the severity of pain associated with the condition.
Expected Outcome: Improved patient comfort and potentially better pain control outcomes in cases of intra-parenchymal hemorrhage.

Trigger condition: In the presence of specific diagnoses like sinus tachycardia, hyponatremia, and hyperlipidemia. Recommended action: Consider adding medications like Metoprolol, Sodium Chloride IV, and Atorvastatin to target the conditions effectively. Expected outcome: Improved management of the diagnosed conditions and potential reduction in associated symptoms and complications.

Trigger condition: When adjusting prescriptions for cardiovascular and electrolyte-related issues. Recommended action: Monitor closely for drug interactions and adverse effects when adding new medications. Expected outcome: Minimization of risks and optimized therapeutic benefits.
Trigger condition: In cases of intra-parenchymal hemorrhage with pain symptoms, Consider adding a suitable pain relief medication.
Recommended action: Include Acetaminophen or an appropriate pain relief medication in the prescription.
Expected outcome: Enhanced pain management with the integration of a safe and effective analgesic, promoting patient comfort without compromising existing treatment.
If patient diagnosed with pneumonia, consider prescribing appropriate antibiotics such as Levofloxacin as per guidelines.
Ensure modifications to medications align with the patient's specific condition and any comorbidities, while still adhering to standard protocols.
When removing medications, evaluate the rationale behind each decision to prevent compromising the overall treatment plan for the patient.
